channel.title: Comments on: Do not use spaces or other invalid characters in your column names
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
@Chattabaugh

I agree that there are times when numbers in columns names are acceptable. Please understand that SQLCop will sometimes raise false positives, as such, you are free to ignore any warning it gives.

The items that appear in the list of checks are warnings.

item.title: By: Chattabaugh
item.dc:creator: Chattabaugh
item.content:encoded:
Columns such as ICD9, CO2E_Value, and even Zip5 are valid column names that do not signify unnormalized data.
Unnormalized data would requrie two columns with the same name but a sequential number.

Also in cases were Secquences are requires, we force the name to use “Alternative” words such as “Primary” and “secondary” (i.e. PriamryAddress, SecondaryAddress as opposed to Address1, Address2)

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
@sumit,

In some cases, numbers in a column name may indicate that the table is not normalized. If you have a CurrentDate2, CurrentDate3, etc…. then your table is not normalized and spelling out the number makes no difference.

item.title: By: sumit Jain
item.dc:creator: sumit Jain
item.description: Hello,<br /> If a column name is CurrentDate1 then as per your comment we make it as CurrentDateOne. will it be fine & correct way..
item.content:encoded:
Hello,
If a column name is CurrentDate1 then as per your comment we make it as CurrentDateOne. will it be fine & correct way..

item.title: By: niikola
item.dc:creator: niikola
item.description: I do not agree with marking numbers as not allowed in column names as there are a lot of situations where column name contains number inside - of course not as leading character.
item.content:encoded: I do not agree with marking numbers as not allowed in column names as there are a lot of situations where column name contains number inside – of course not as leading character.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Naomi, table names or actually any object name (proc, database, function, view etc etc) should all follow the same kind of naming conventions
item.content:encoded: Naomi, table names or actually any object name (proc, database, function, view etc etc) should all follow the same kind of naming conventions
